Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (.raw_text: Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (MA 1995) (landlord liability for negligence in premises maintenance)
Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (.proposition: - Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (MA 1995) (landlord liability for negligence in premises maintenance)
Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns the scope of governmental immunity and the standard of wanton or reckless conduct required for liability under a recreational use statute, not ordinary landlord liability for negligent premises maintenance. The SJC ultimately holds that the Commonwealth’s conduct, while arguably negligent, did not rise to recklessness, and it analogizes to other premises cases only to illustrate the recklessness threshold. It therefore does not establish or affirm any general rule about landlord liability for negligence in maintaining premises.
Sandler v. Commonwealth, 419 Mass. 334 (.relevant_excerpt: “Nevertheless, the degree of the risk of injury in this case does not meet the standard that we have established for recklessness… this case, which involves a persistent failure to remedy defects in a tunnel on a traveled bikeway, simply does not present a level of dangerousness that warrants liability under G. L. c. 21, § 17C, for the MDC’s inaction. … The level of fault in this case, measured by the degree of risk of serious injury, is more consistent with our cases in which we have held that the evidence did not warrant a finding of wanton or reckless conduct.”

Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.raw_text: Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323 (MA 1982) (duty to protect tenants from foreseeable harm)
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.proposition: - Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323 (MA 1982) (duty to protect tenants from foreseeable harm)
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: The case involves a tavern’s duty to protect members of the traveling public from foreseeable harm caused by serving alcohol to an intoxicated patron who then drives, not a landlord’s or property owner’s duty to protect tenants. The court’s analysis is framed entirely in terms of tavern keeper liability, statutory duties under the liquor laws, and foreseeability of harm to highway travelers, not duties owed to tenants or persons in a tenant-like relationship. Thus, citing Cimino for a general ‘duty to protect tenants from foreseeable harm’ misstates its holding and context.
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: “It is only necessary for the plaintiff to prove that the defendant took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. … Therefore, evidence that a tavern keeper served intoxicating liquor to a patron the tavern keeper knew, or reasonably should have known, was intoxicated is sufficient to warrant a jury finding that the tavern keeper took such a risk, and that injuries to a highway traveler… were proximately caused by the tavern keeper’s negligent act.”

Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 14.raw_text: Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 140 (MA 1976) (landlord's liability for injuries on leased premises)
Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 14.proposition: - Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 140 (MA 1976) (landlord's liability for injuries on leased premises)
Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 14.support_reasoning: The opinion in Agis v. Howard Johnson Co. does not address landlord–tenant law or a landlord’s liability for injuries on leased premises. Instead, it recognizes and defines a tort claim for intentional or reckless infliction of severe emotional distress (and a related loss of consortium claim) arising from an employment termination. Thus, citing this case for landlord liability on leased premises misstates its holding and subject matter.
Agis v. Howard Johnson Co., 371 Mass. 14.relevant_excerpt: “This case raises the issue… whether a cause of action exists in this Commonwealth for the intentional or reckless infliction of severe emotional distress without resulting bodily injury. Counts 1 and 2… were brought by the plaintiff Debra Agis… to recover damages for mental anguish and emotional distress allegedly caused by her summary dismissal from such employment.”

Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App..raw_text: Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 381 (MA App. Ct. 2003) (breach of duty of care by a property management company)
Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App..proposition: - Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 381 (MA App. Ct. 2003) (breach of duty of care by a property management company)
Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a criminal defendant’s motion to withdraw a guilty plea based on alleged ineffective assistance of counsel in advising him to stipulate to his HIV status during a grand jury investigation. It does not involve a property management company, premises liability, or any breach of duty of care in a civil context. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that it is a case about breach of duty of care by a property management company.
Boyd v. Jamaica Hospital, 58 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: "The defendant appeals from the denial of his motion to withdraw his plea of guilty to an indictment charging him with an assault with intent to commit murder. His sole contention on appeal is that his trial counsel was ineffective in advising him to enter into a stipulation that he is infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)... We affirm the denial of the motion."

Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass.raw_text: Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass. 246 (MA 1967) (property owner's liability for negligence)
Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass.proposition: - Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass. 246 (MA 1967) (property owner's liability for negligence)
Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with cancellation of a long-term lease as a cloud on title in the Land Court, based on its limited purpose, inequitable terms, and nonperformance. It does not address tort or premises liability, nor any general rule about a property owner's liability for negligence. Accordingly, citing this case for ‘property owner's liability for negligence’ is inaccurate.
Kenavan v. Alfred L. Mudge Co., 353 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The final decree was correct upon the basis of the facts properly found by the master, viz. that the lease was given for a limited purpose which could not be accomplished, and that the terms of the lease were inequitable. … Dowd, as owner of the leased premises (found by the master to be worth $80,000), is now entitled to have the lease, a cloud upon her title, cancelled.”

Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc..raw_text: Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc., 17 Mass. App. Ct. 78 (MA App. Ct. 1983) (landlord's duty of care in maintaining premises)
Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc..proposition: - Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc., 17 Mass. App. Ct. 78 (MA App. Ct. 1983) (landlord's duty of care in maintaining premises)
Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal procedure case about a District Court judge’s authority to dismiss criminal complaints with prejudice and a Superior Court judge’s power to disregard that dismissal when proceeding on related indictments. It does not concern landlords, tenants, premises liability, or any duty of care in maintaining premises. Therefore, citing this case for a landlord’s duty of care in maintaining premises is inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Carey v. Maplewood Shopping Center, Inc..relevant_excerpt: "We are of opinion that the Superior Court judge had the power to decide whether (considering the whole situation) the District Court judge exceeded his authority in dismissing the complaints ‘with prejudice.’ ... In light of the failure to comply with the Brandano procedures, it was error to dismiss the complaints, let alone dismiss them ‘with prejudice.’ We are of opinion that the District Court judge abused his discretion and exceeded his authority in allowing the defendant’s motion over the objection of the Commonwealth."

Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Ma.proposition: - Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Mass. 177 (MA 1979) (proximate cause in negligence cases)
Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Ma.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a short concurrence by Justice Kaplan focused on premises-liability status categories (trespasser/invitee/licensee), not on defining or applying proximate cause in negligence cases. Nothing in the quoted text discusses causation standards or proximate cause analysis. Without additional portions of the opinion, this excerpt does not support the proposition that Soule is authority on proximate cause; the citation, as shown, appears unrelated to that specific legal principle.
Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "Concurring, I must, in contrast to the Chief Justice, express disappointment at the intimation in the next-to-last paragraph of the court’s opinion that the liability of an occupier for negligence might still be made to turn in this jurisdiction on the mere circumstance, without more, that the plaintiff had the common law status of a so called trespasser at the time of the occurrence in suit."

Mueller v. McDonnell, 467 Mass. 316 (MA.relevant_excerpt: “In December, 2008, a Superior Court jury convicted the defendant of murder in the first degree on the theory of felony-murder, with armed robbery as the predicate felony… On December 21, 2005, a Suffolk County grand jury indicted the defendant for murder in the first degree, G. L. c. 265, § 1, and armed robbery, G. L. c. 265, § 17.… The judgment of conviction of murder in the first degree is affirmed.”
